summary.seg: This manuscript is a working autograph, first written in Crete by its author Michael Apostolis, or Apostolios (c. 1422-c. 1480), probably in 1462. It contains a tract produced as part of an intellectual controversy over the relative merits of Plato and Aristotle, partiuclarly with regard to the compatibility of their theories with Christianity. The debate involved most of the leading Greek-speaking scholars of the mid-15th century, many of whom had settled in Italy. The manuscript contains numerous alterations and expansions of the initial draft.

The author was a native of Constantinople who had received an advanced education there under the famous teacher John Argyropoulos (c. 1416-1486)Johannes Argyropulus. Apostolis was also a follower of the zealous Platonist and alleged neo-pagan George Gemistos Plethon (c. 1360-1452)Gemistus Plethon, George, active 15th century, and around 1449 he had felt compelled to address an oration to the emperor defending himself against accusations that he had become a worshipper of the ancient Greek gods.

When Constantinople fell to the Ottomans, Apostolis was captured and held prisoner for some months. Having secured his freedom, he sought the patronage of Cardinal Bessarion (1403-1472)Bessarion, Cardinal, 1403-1472, the most distinguished of the Byzantine exiles in Italy. Failing to secure the teaching work he sought in Italy, Apostolis settled in Venetian-ruled Crete, where he was commissioned by Bessarion to acquire manuscripts for him, as part of the cardinal's efforts to preserve Greek learning in the face of the Ottoman conquests. He also worked as a scribe and apparently commissioned others to copy manuscripts for Bessarion and other patrons. Throughout his life he continued to petition the cardinal with complaints of poverty and unsuccessful requests to help him establish a school on Crete, or preferably to find a teaching position elsewhere.

The controversy over Plato and Aristotle originated with arguments for the superiority of Plato and the deficiencies of Aristotle put forward by Plethon, summed up in a work he released in about 1448. This line of argument arose out of Plethon's participation in the Byzantine delegation to the Council of Ferrara-Florence in 1437-1438, where Union had been concluded between the Eastern and Western Churches. Confronted at close quarters by the dominant position of Aristotle in western European scholarship, Plethon reacted vehemently. The dispute burst fully into life in the later 1450s, with a flurry of interventions on one side or the other. These included a criticism of Plato's views on the prior existence of universals to individuals which was written in 1459 by Theodore Gazes (c. 1400-c. 1475)Gazes, Theodoros, approximately 1400-approximately 1475, a Byzantine exile teaching in Italy, structured as a dialogue between himself and Plethon. It was to this text that Apostolis responded with the far more polemical refutation contained in this manuscript, laced with personal invective against Gazes, including allegations of homosexuality and prostitution. Apostolis not only affirms the superiority of Plato over Aristotle, but asserts that Plethon too was superior to Aristotle and his contemporaries.

The text begins with a preface addressed to Bessarion, himself a former student of Plethon and an enthusiast for the philosophy of Plato. Gazes's tract was written in response to an essay by Bessarion regarding Aristotle's Περὶ οὐσίας (De substantia), in which the cardinal had sought an accommodation between Aristotle's views and Plethon's arguments against them. Apostolis presumably hoped that his intervention against Gazes would win him favour with his patron. He does not, however, seem to have presented the text to Bessarion, who became aware of it only indirectly. Apostolis sent a copy to a friend in Rome, a Cypriot monk named IsaiasIsaias Cyprius ca. um 1430, who circulated it at his request in the scholarly community. One of those who read it was Andronikos Kallistos (d. 1478)Andronicus Callistus, -1478, another Constantinopolitan exile and a cousin of Gazes, who wrote a response defending Gazes and Aristotle and then sent both texts to Bessarion.

Whatever hopes Apostolis had entertained of pleasing Bessarion with this work, his effort backfired. The extreme nature of his polemic prompted a letter from Bessarion to Apostolis, dated 19 May 1462, in which the cardinal reprimanded Apostolis for his attacks on Gazes and Aristotle, and proclaimed his own great respect for both of the ancient philosophers. Gazes was himself one of Bessarion's protégés, while the cardinal, for all his own Platonist leanings, was committed to upholding the reputation of Aristotle, the chief philosophical authority of the Catholic Church.

Despite this blunder, Bessarion continued to employ Apostolis as before, and the incident failed to deter the author from being drawn back into the controversy. Another refutation of his tract was produced by another Byzantine exile, the Professor of Greek at Padua Demetrios Chalkokondyles (c. 1423-1511)Calcondila, Demetrio, 1423-1511, prompting Apostolis in 1467 to write another vituperative response, featuring mockery of Chalkokondyles's surname and aspersions on the sexual propriety of his mother.

The relationship between this manuscript and the surviving copies of the text is unclear. Its text differs greatly from that found across the rest of the textual tradition. Many passages found here are absent from the other manuscripts, including the many additions to the text which Apostolis made in the margins, but also much of the original content. Thus its seems likely that the copies derive from some other archetype, probably the manuscript sent to Isaias for circulation. It appears that Apostolis continued to rework the tract after he had first made it public, expanding on his first recension in the writing of the original text here and then expanding further in his revisions. He perhaps intended to improve on his first attempt before presenting the amended version to his patron. While for the most part the text of this manuscript is fuller than that of the copies, it lacks their last passage, which draws the argument to a conclusion, and ends rather abruptly. Hence it seems likely that the text here was left unfinished. It may be that Apostolis abandoned it on the arrival of Bessarion's letter, with its negative verdict on the whole undertaking.

msItem.title: Tract against the objections of Theodore Gazes against Plethon regarding Aristotle's De substantia
msItem.filiation: This manuscript is a working autograph of the text, and forms the basis of Powell's edition. It does not appear among the manuscripts consulted for the subsequent edition of Ludwig Mohler, Aus Bessarions Gelehrtenkreis: Abhandlungen, Reden, Briefe von Bessarion, Theodoros Gazes, Michael Apostolios, Andronikos Kallistos, Georgios Trapezountios, Niccolò Perotti, Niccolò Capranica (Kardinal Bessarion als Theologe, Humanist und Staatsmann, vol. 3) (Paderborn 1942), Quellen und Forschungen aus dem Gebiete der Geschichte 24, pp. 159-169. The text appearing in this manuscript differs very substantially from the bulk of the tradition and the Mohler edition derived from it.
msItem.rubric: f. 1r Μιχαήλου Ἀποστόλου τοῦ Βυζαντίου· πρὸς τὰς ὑπὲρ Ἀριστοτέλους Περὶ οὐσίας κατὰ Πλήθωνος, Θεοδώρου τοῦ Γάζη ἀντιλείψεις:- Ἐπιστολὴ· πρὸς τὸν σοφώτατον Βησσαρίω
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Οἶδα σε θειότατε καρδιναλέων· δυοῖν τούτοιν ὄντοιν ἡγεμόνοιν τῶν λόγων
msItem.explicit: f. 21v τὸν δοξομανῆ κὰν τούτῳ Ἀριστοτέλη μιμούμενος

support.material: Western paper, folded in quarto, with 6 chainlines per leaf. Watermark: Bull's head ( c. 80 31 ) in the gutter, similar to Briquet 14795, 14801. These examples are dated to 1465-1474.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers [i-vi] + 1-22 + [vii-xii], in pencil, in Arabic numerals, recto, upper right.

collation.p: The manuscript consists of 3 quires, all quaternia.

list.item: Quire 38-2 ff. 17-22 The last two folios have been cancelled, without loss of text.

collation.signatures: There are original quire signatures in Greek numerals, in brown ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower right. They survive on all quires (αʹ-γʹ).

supportDesc.condition: There are small tears to the edges of some folios, and some water staining.

layoutDesc.layout:
A single column of 24 lines.
135 85
The author's additions to the text have sometimes been made by continuing it directly into the lower margin with additional lines of greater length. Some of this text has been lost to cropping.

handNote.p: The manuscript was written by Michael Apostolis in mixed minuscule script, with variable slant, in brown ink, with modest variation in letter size. There are deletions by strikethrough.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings usually appear only at the end of lines, but occasionally elsewhere. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot. Accents are sometimes joined to breathings.
The modern eta, modern nu and loop epsilon are present.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in red ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: The beginning of sections are marked by minor initials in red ink.
Some spaces have been left for initials which have not been added.

additions.p: There are extensive marginal annotations and additions to the text by the author.

There are marginal annotations in brown ink, identifiying authors cited. The same hand added a note in Latin on f. [i] recto citing Oxford manuscripts containing other works relevant to the same controversy.
A note of content in Latin in brown ink has been added to f. [i] recto: Michael Apostolius. pro Plethono contra Theodorum Gazam de essentia defensio.
Further marginal notes of authors cited have been added in pencil, along with a list on f. [i] recto of works relevant to the controversy to be examined.

binding.p: 17-century limp vellum binding, with plain pastedowns. The classmark appears on patches on the spine.

history.origin: The manuscript is a working autograph, written and expanded by the author, Michael Apostolis (PLP 1201; RGK I 278, II 379, III 454) in Crete between 1459 and 1462. The tract to which it responded was produced in 1459, while Bessarions's letter written in response to the text it contains is dated 19 May 1462. Its apparently unfinished state suggests that Apostolis may still have been working on it in 1462, until interrupted by the arrival of Bessarion's reprimand.
history.acquisition: Donated by the antiquary Roger Gale (1672-1744)Gale, Roger, 1672-1744 in 1738.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

analytic.title: Un Περὶ τῆς οὐσίας faussement attribué a Michel Apostolès
